passages.text: The only thing that makes life possible is permanent, intolerable uncertainty; not knowing what comes next.
We live in capitalism. Its power seems inescapable. So did the divine right of kings.
passages.context: Historical perspective on seemingly permanent systems

passages.text: The only thing that makes life possible is permanent, intolerable uncertainty; not knowing what comes next.
passages.context: Uncertainty as the condition of living

passages.text: You cannot buy the revolution. You cannot make the revolution. You can only be the revolution.
passages.context: Revolution as way of being, not event

passages.text: To learn which questions are unanswerable, and not to answer them: this skill is most needful in times of stress and darkness.
passages.context: Knowing when not to seek answers

passages.text: Light is the left hand of darkness, and darkness the right hand of light.
passages.context: Opposites as aspects of one reality

passages.text: We are volcanoes. When we women offer our experience as our truth, as human truth, all the maps change.
The exercise of imagination is dangerous to those who profit from the way things are because it has the power to show that the way things are is not permanent, not universal, not necessary.
passages.source: Introduction to The Left Hand of Darkness

passages.text: To oppose something is to maintain it.
The story is not in the ending but in the telling.
True voyage is return.
passages.context: The journey that brings you back transformed

passages.text: A man who doesn't detest a bad government is a fool. And if there were such a thing as a good government on earth, it would be a great joy to serve it.
The trouble is that we have a bad habit, encouraged by pedants and sophisticates, of considering happiness as something rather stupid. Only pain is intellectual, only evil interesting.
passages.source: The Ones Who Walk Away from Omelas
passages.context: Critique of intellectual bias toward suffering

passages.text: Words are events, they do things, change things. They transform both speaker and hearer.
My imagination makes me human and makes me a fool; it gives me all the world and exiles me from it.
When you light a candle, you also cast a shadow.
What sane person could live in this world and not be crazy?
To see a candle's light, one must take it into a dark place.
passages.context: Darkness as necessary context for light

passages.text: Those who build walls are their own prisoners.
What is an anarchist? One who, choosing, accepts the responsibility of choice.
